A Hybrid Architecture for
Federated and Centralized Learning

Abstract

Many of the machine learning tasks rely on centralized learning (CL), which requires the transmission of local datasets from the clients to a parameter server (PS) entailing huge communication overhead. To overcome this, federated learning (FL) has been suggested as a promising tool, wherein the clients send only the model updates to the PS instead of the whole dataset. However, FL demands powerful computational resources from the clients. In practice, not all the clients have sufficient computational resources to participate in training. To address this common scenario, we propose a more efficient approach called hybrid federated and centralized learning (HFCL), wherein only the clients with sufficient resources employ FL, while the remaining ones send their datasets to the PS, which computes the model on behalf of them. Then, the model parameters are aggregated at the PS. To improve the efficiency of dataset transmission, we propose two different techniques: i) increased computation-per-client and ii) sequential data transmission. Notably, the HFCL frameworks outperform FL with up to 20%percent2020\% improvement in the learning accuracy when only half of the clients perform FL while having 50%percent5050\% less communication overhead than CL since all the clients collaborate on the learning process with their datasets.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, federated learning, centralized learning, edge intelligence, edge efficiency.

I Introduction

The ever growing increase in the number of connected devices in the last few years has led to a surge in the amount of data generated by mobile phones, connected vehicles, drones and internet of things (IoT) devices due to the rapid development of various emerging applications, such as artificial intelligence (AI), virtual and augmented reality (VAR), autonomous vehicles (AVs), and machine-to-machine communications [2, 3]. According to international telecommunication union (ITU), the global mobile traffic is expected to reach 607607607 EB by 2025. Moreover, AVs are expected to generate approximately 20 TB/day/vehicle [4]. In order to process and extract useful information from the huge amount of data, machine learning (ML) has been recognized as a promising tool for emerging technologies, such as IoT [5], AV [6], and next generation wireless communications [7, 8, 9] due to its success in image/speech recognition, natural language processing, etc [2]. These applications require huge amount of data to be processed and learned by a learning model, often an artificial neural network (ANN), by extracting the features from the raw data and providing a “meaning” to the input via constructing a model-free data mapping with huge number of learnable parameters [7]. The implementation of these learning models demands powerful computation resources, such as graphics processing units (GPUs). Therefore, huge learning models, massive amount of training data, and powerful computation infrastructure are the main driving factors defining the success of ML algorithms [7, 3].

Many of the ML tasks are based on centralized learning (CL) algorithms, which train powerful ANNs at a parameter server (PS) [2, 10, 11]. While CL inherently assumes the availability of datasets at the PS, this may not be possible for the wireless edge devices (clients), such as mobile phones, connected vehicles, and IoT devices, which need to send their datasets to the PS. Transmitting the collected datasets to the PS in a reliable manner may be too costly in terms of energy, latency, and bandwidth [12]. For example, in LTE (long term evolution), a single frame of 555 MHz bandwidth and 101010 ms duration can carry only 600060006000 complex symbols [13], whereas the size of the whole dataset can be on the order of hundreds of thousands symbols [14]. As a result, CL-based techniques require huge bandwidth and communication overhead during training.

In order to provide a practically viable alternative to CL-based training, federated learning (FL) has been proposed to exploit the processing capability of the edge devices and the local datasets of the clients [11, 15, 16]. In FL, the clients compute and transmit the model parameters to the PS instead of their local datasets as in CL to collaboratively train the learning model. The collected model updates are aggregated at the PS and then broadcast to the clients to further update the learning parameters iteratively. Since FL does not access the whole dataset at once, it has slightly lower learning performance than that of CL. However, FL is communication-efficient and privacy-preserving since it keeps the datasets at the clients. Recently, FL has been applied to image classification [15, 12, 17], speech recognition [18] and wireless communications [19, 20]. In particular, various wireless network architectures exploiting FL have been investigated, such as cellular networks [21, 22, 13], vehicular networks [6], unmanned aerial vehicles [23], IoT networks [24], and for the design of physical layer applications [25]. In these works, the FL architectures rely on the fact that all of the clients are capable of model computation, which may require powerful parallel processing units, such as GPUs. However, this may not always be possible in practice due to the diversity of the devices with different computation capabilities, such as mobile phones, vehicular components and IoT devices. When the edge devices lack of sufficient computational power, they cannot perform model computation, and thus become unable to participate in the learning process. To address this problem, client selection algorithms have been developed. In [26] and [27], trusted clients and the ones with sufficient computational resources are participated in FL-based training. However, these studies do not allow the clients that are not selected to participate in the training process, regardless of their computational capability.

In this work, we introduce a hybrid FL and CL (HFCL) framework for which the main motivation is to effectively train a learning model regardless of the computational capability of the clients. By exploiting their computational resources, the clients that are capable of model computation perform FL while the remaining clients resort to CL and send their datasets to the PS, which computes the corresponding model parameters on behalf of them (see Fig. 1). At the beginning of the training, the clients are designated as inactive (i.e., CL is applied) or active (i.e., FL is employed) depending on their computational capabilities. That is, the clients are called active if they have adequate computational resources, e.g., GPUs, to compute the model parameters, whereas the clients are called inactive otherwise in such a case, hence they send their datasets to the PS, which computes the model parameters on behalf of them. The PS, then, optimizes the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the maximum communication delay of the clients. During model training, both active and inactive clients are synchronized and the training process is conducted iteratively as in FL, where the model parameters are aggregated in each communication round between the PS and the active clients. Prior to the model training, the inactive clients transmit the datasets to the PS so that the PS can compute model updates on behalf of them during training. In the meantime, the active clients perform model computation. Once the model parameters corresponding to active (computed on device) and inactive (computed on PS) clients are collected at the PS, they are aggregated and broadcast to the active clients only so that they can compute the model parameters in the next iteration. Since the PS computes the model parameters on behalf of the inactive clients, it is not necessary to broadcast model updates to them. As a result, the proposed HFCL approach provides a trade-off among learning performance, communication overhead, privacy, and the clients’ computational resources (see, e.g., Table I). While the usage of CL enables higher learning performance and lower dependence on the clients’ computational resources, FL enjoys enhanced privacy and less communication overhead. In contrast, HFCL jointly employs CL and FL. Therefore, it enjoys less communication overhead than CL; higher performance and more flexibility than FL, while it is less privacy-preserving and lower communication-efficient than FL. Thus, HFCL can be particularly useful when the dataset does not include privacy-sensitive content, e.g., physical layer data [25].

Although the integration of FL and CL may seem straightforward, there are two main challenges in HFCL. First, training time of HFCL is longer than FL since the inactive clients need to transmit their datasets to the PS prior to the training. In other words, the active clients should wait for the inactive clients at the beginning of the training until the dataset transmission for inactive clients is completed so that they can synchronously participate in model training. To circumvent this problem and provide efficient model training, we propose sequential dataset transmission (HFCL-SDT) where the inactive clients’ datasets are divided into smaller blocks to complete the dataset transmission quicker. Second, the learning accuracy of HFCL is lower than CL since the model parameters corresponding to the active clients are noisy due to wireless transmission. To improve the learning accuracy, we propose increased computation-per-client (HFCL-ICpC) approach where the training continues at the active clients during the transmission of inactive clients’ datasets instead of waiting idle for the inactive clients as in basic HFCL, in which the active clients wait for the completion of dataset transmission. Thus, HFCL-ICpC improves the learning performance as compared to HFCL without increasing the delay due to dataset generation. In summary, HFCL-ICpC improves the learning performance while HFCL-SDT reduces the dataset transmission time per communication round. Inspired from [15], where the model parameters are infrequently aggregated at the clients, we develop a new approach to first aggregate the model parameters at the clients until the transmission of the inactive clients’ datasets is completed, then continue aggregating the models at the PS. Compared to [15], our technique achieves a better learning performance as well as flexibility on the hardware requirements since the learning model can be trained on the whole dataset even if a part of the clients do not have computational resources. Compared to our preliminary work [1], this paper introduces HFCL-ICpC approach to improve learning accuracy, theoretical analysis on the convergence of HFCL, and the implementation of the 3-D object detection scenario. While the term hybrid is used in some recent FL-based works in terms of client scheduling [28], data partitioning [29] and data security [30], this is the first work employing a hybrid architecture of FL and CL by exploiting the hardware capability of the edge devices. The main contributions of this paper are as follows:

  • •

    We propose a hybrid FL/CL approach to manage the diverse computational capabilities of the edge clients. In the proposed approach, only the clients, which have adequate computational resources perform FL while the remaining clients perform CL.

  • •

    We show that the performance of HFCL converges to that of FL (CL) when the number of active clients increases (decreases). Specifically when the active and inactive clients are partitioned equally, the proposed HFCL approach exhibits up to 20%percent2020\% improvement in the learning accuracy compared to FL. HFCL also enjoys 50%percent5050\% less communication overhead with only 2%percent22\% loss in the learning accuracy as compared to CL.

  • •

    To efficiently transmit the datasets of the inactive clients to the PS, we propose the HFCL-SDT and HFCL-ICpC techniques to achieve no interruption of the learning process. Compared to FL, the proposed techniques are effective due to faster convergence rates and higher learning accuracy together with less communication delay due to less dataset transmission.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, CL and FL frameworks are presented. Then, we introduce the proposed HFCL, HFCL-ICpC, and HFCL-SDT approach in Section III, IV, and V. In Section VI, we investigate the convergence and the communication overhead of the HFCL approach. Section VII presents the numerical simulation results, and we summarize the paper in Section VIII with concluding remarks.

II Preliminaries:
Centralized and Federated Learning

In ML, we are interested in constructing a learning model that forms a non-linear relationship between the two data pairs: the input and the label. Here, 𝒳(i)∈ℝUx×Vxsuperscript𝒳𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑈𝑥subscript𝑉𝑥\mathcal{X}^{(i)}\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{x}\times V_{x}} and 𝒴(i)∈ℝUy×Vysuperscript𝒴𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑈𝑦subscript𝑉𝑦\mathcal{Y}^{(i)}\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{y}\times V_{y}} denote the i𝑖ith input and label pairs of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, respectively. The training of the ML model takes place by focusing on a scenario, wherein K𝐾K clients collaborate on optimizing 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} for the ML task.

II-A Centralized Learning

In CL, the model has access to the whole dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, which is collected by the PS from the clients (see Fig. 1a). II-B Federated Learning

Compared to CL, FL does not involve the transmission of datasets to the PS. Instead, the model training is performed at the clients while the model parameters produced by the clients are aggregated at the PS, as shown in Fig. 1b. Consequently, the solution of the optimization problem in FL settings takes place at the client and the PS side as follows

in which, each client optimizes its model parameters 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} based on ℱk​(𝜽)subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) as in (4a) and transmits 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} to the PS, where the the model parameters are aggregated as in (4b). For an effective solution of (4a), gradient descent (GD) algorithm is used iteratively such that an optimal local solution is obtained for each iteration. The PS and the clients exchange the updated model parameters until convergence [11, 31, 15]. In particular, the parameter update at the t𝑡tth iteration is performed as

where 𝜽k(t)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)} denotes the model parameters at the k𝑘kth client for the t𝑡tth communication round/iteration with t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T, T𝑇T is the total number of iterations, η𝜂\eta is the learning rate, and 𝐠​(𝜽k(t))=∇ℱk​(𝜽k(t))𝐠superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡∇subscriptℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\mathbf{g}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})=\nabla\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}) denotes the P×1𝑃1P\times 1 gradient vector, computed at the k𝑘kth client, based on 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝜽k(t)superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}. Consequently, we can rewrite (4) as

which performs GD and iteratively reaches convergence.

III Hybrid Federated and Centralized Learning

In this section, we introduce the proposed HFCL framework by taking into account the computational capability of the clients so that all clients can contribute to the learning task with their datasets regardless of their ability to compute the model parameters. The motivation is based on the following inadequacy observed in practice. In ML tasks, training a model requires huge computational power to compute the model parameters. This requirement cannot always be satisfied by the computational capabilities of the client devices. For this reason, an effective training of the ML model, we propose a hybrid training framework that accounts for the computational capabilities of the clients. Specifically, we assume that only a portion of the clients with sufficient computational power performs FL, while the remaining clients, which suffer from inadequate computational capability, send their datasets to the PS for model computation, as illustrated in Fig. 1c.

Let us define the set of clients who perform CL, i.e., sending datasets to the PS, and the ones who perform FL, i.e., transmitting the model parameters to the PS as ℒ={1,…,L}ℒ1…𝐿\mathcal{L}=\{1,\dots,L\} and ℒ¯={L+1,…,K}¯ℒ𝐿1…𝐾\bar{\mathcal{L}}=\{L+1,\dots,K\}, respectively, where 𝒦=ℒ​⋃ℒ¯𝒦ℒ¯ℒ\mathcal{K}=\mathcal{L}\bigcup\bar{\mathcal{L}} and ℒ∩ℒ¯=∅ℒ¯ℒ\mathcal{L}\cap\bar{\mathcal{L}}=\emptyset. Furthermore, we refer to the clients in ℒℒ\mathcal{L} and ℒ¯¯ℒ\bar{\mathcal{L}} as inactive and active clients, respectively. The determination of client’s condition (i.e., active/inactive) can be done by the devices sending information on their computational resources to the PS [26, 27]. By exploiting the availability of computational resources of the clients, the HFCL problem can be formulated as optimization of model parameters at the client and PS as follows

Client::Clientabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{Client:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽k=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℱk​(𝜽),k∈ℒ¯,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽𝑘¯ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, (7a)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽k=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℱk​(𝜽),k∈ℒ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽𝑘ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\mathcal{L}, (7b)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽=∑k∈𝒦Dk​𝜽kD,𝜽subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘𝐷\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}=\frac{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}{D}, (7c)

where the PS actively participates in the model computation process and computes 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} for k∈ℒ𝑘ℒk\in\mathcal{L} since the inactive clients do not have sufficient computational capabilities. Once the model parameters are computed, the PS aggregates them as in (7c).

III-A Noisy Learning Model

In HFCL, both the model parameters and the datasets are corrupted by noise due to wireless links [31, 20]. Compared to the noise in the datasets (for image classification, see Section VII), the effect of noisy model parameters is significant since it directly corrupts the learning model [1]. During model transmission for k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, the noisy model parameters at the PS and the clients are respectively given by

Client::Clientabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{Client:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽~k=𝜽~+Δ​𝜽~k,k∈ℒ¯,formulae-sequencesubscript~𝜽𝑘~𝜽Δsubscript~𝜽𝑘𝑘¯ℒ\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}+\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k},k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, (8a)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽~=1D​{∑k∈ℒDk​𝜽k+∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​(𝜽k+Δ​𝜽k)}.~𝜽1𝐷subscript𝑘ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘Δsubscript𝜽𝑘\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\frac{1}{D}\bigg{\{}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{L}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})\bigg{\}}. (8b)

In (8b), 𝜽k∈ℒ¯subscript𝜽𝑘¯ℒ\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}} denotes the true model parameter transmitted from the active clients, while Δ​𝜽k∈ℒ¯Δsubscript𝜽𝑘¯ℒ\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}} represents the noise term added onto 𝜽k∈ℒ¯subscript𝜽𝑘¯ℒ\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}, which is observed at the PS. After the model aggregation in (8b), 𝜽~~𝜽\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}} is broadcast to the active clients and it is corrupted by the noise term Δ​𝜽~kΔsubscript~𝜽𝑘\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k} as in (8a) for k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}. Notice that the first term on the right hand side of (8b) includes no noise corruption since the model parameters are computed at the PS. Let us rewrite (8b) as

𝜽~=1D​∑k∈𝒦Dk​𝜽k+1D​∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​Δ​𝜽k.~𝜽1𝐷subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘1𝐷subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘Δsubscript𝜽𝑘\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}. (9)

Therefore, using (4b), (9) becomes

𝜽~=𝜽+Δ​𝜽~,~𝜽𝜽~Δ𝜽\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\boldsymbol{\theta}+\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}, (10)

where Δ​𝜽~=1D​∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​Δ​𝜽k~Δ𝜽1𝐷subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘Δsubscript𝜽𝑘\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} is the aggregated noise term due to the model transmission from the active clients to the PS. Without loss of generality, we assume that both noise terms due to model transmission in client-PS and PS-client links, i.e., Δ​𝜽~~Δ𝜽\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}} and Δ​𝜽~kΔsubscript~𝜽𝑘\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k} (k∈ℒ¯)𝑘¯ℒ(k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}), are additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) vectors [31, 20]111While the Gaussian assumption is widely used in the relevant literature [20, 32, 17, 31], it is worth noting that this assumption is not completely satisfied in practice due to the source/channel coding and quantization operations during the transmission of the model parameters. In addition, recent works, e.g., [33], show that the noise on the model updates can also be modeled as unimodal symmetric distribution, which is close to Gaussian distribution.. Hence, regarding the aggregation noise at the PS, we have 𝔼​{Δ​𝜽~}=𝟎𝔼~Δ𝜽0\mathbb{E}\{\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}\}=\mathbf{0} and 𝔼​{Δ​𝜽~​Δ​𝜽~T}=σ~2​𝐈P𝔼~Δ𝜽superscript~Δ𝜽Tsuperscript~𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑃\mathbb{E}\{\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{\textsf{T}}\}=\tilde{\sigma}^{2}\mathbf{I}_{P}. Likewise, at the k𝑘kth active client (k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}), we have 𝔼​{Δ​𝜽~k}=𝟎𝔼Δsubscript~𝜽𝑘0\mathbb{E}\{\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}\}=\mathbf{0}, 𝔼​{Δ​𝜽~k​Δ​𝜽~kT}=σk2​𝐈P𝔼Δsubscript~𝜽𝑘Δsuperscriptsubscript~𝜽𝑘Tsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2subscript𝐈𝑃\mathbb{E}\{\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}^{\textsf{T}}\}={\sigma}_{k}^{2}\mathbf{I}_{P} and 𝔼​{Δ​𝜽k1​Δ​𝜽k2T}=𝟎𝔼Δsubscript𝜽subscript𝑘1Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜽subscript𝑘2T0\mathbb{E}\{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k_{1}}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k_{2}}^{\textsf{T}}\}=\mathbf{0} for k1,k2∈ℒ¯subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2¯ℒk_{1},k_{2}\in\bar{\mathcal{L}} and k1≠k2subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2k_{1}\neq k_{2}. Furthermore, by using (10) and rewriting (8a) as

𝜽~k=𝜽+Δ​𝜽~+Δ​𝜽~k=𝜽+Δ​𝜽~k,subscript~𝜽𝑘𝜽~Δ𝜽Δsubscript~𝜽𝑘𝜽subscript~Δ𝜽𝑘\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}=\boldsymbol{\theta}+\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}+\Delta\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}=\boldsymbol{\theta}+\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}, (11)

we can define the noise on 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} at the k𝑘kth client with variance σ~2+σk2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2}. Specifically, σ~2superscript~𝜎2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} corresponds to the noise term Δ​𝜽~~Δ𝜽\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}} in (10) generated during the model transmission from the active clients to the PS, while σk2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\sigma_{k}^{2} corresponds to Δ​𝜽~ksubscript~Δ𝜽𝑘\widetilde{\Delta{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{k} in (11), which is due to the transmission of the model parameters from the PS to the k𝑘kth active client.

Upon the above analysis on the noise corruption, it is clear that two different noise corruptions occur during training: noise corruption with σ~2superscript~𝜎2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} and σ~2+σ~k2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript~𝜎𝑘2\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\tilde{\sigma}_{k}^{2} for inactive and active clients, respectively. In the sequel, we modify the loss functions used in the training process according to the noise corruption to provide an expectation-based convergence [15, 17].

Let us first consider the loss function for active clients to solve (7a). In order to solve the local problem in (7a) effectively, the loss function should be modified to take into account the effect of noise. Thus, we define a regularized loss function ℱ¯k​(𝜽)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) as

ℱ¯k​(𝜽)=ℱk​(𝜽)+(σ~2+σk2)​‖𝐠​(𝜽k)‖2,subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2superscriptnorm𝐠subscript𝜽𝑘2\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+(\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2})||\mathbf{g}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})||^{2}, (12)

where σ~2+σk2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2} describes the total noise term added onto 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} at the k𝑘kth client (k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}) in (11). The loss function in (12) is widely used in stochastic optimization [34] and it can be obtained via a first-order Taylor expansion of the expectation-based loss 𝔼​{‖ℱk​(𝜽+Δ​𝜽~k)‖2}𝔼superscriptnormsubscriptℱ𝑘𝜽subscript~Δ𝜽𝑘2\mathbb{E}\{||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}+\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k})||^{2}\}, which can be approximately written as

𝔼{||ℱk(𝜽+\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\{||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}+ Δ​𝜽~k)||2}≈𝔼{||ℱk(𝜽)+Δ​𝜽~k∇ℱk(𝜽)||2},\displaystyle\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k})||^{2}\}\approx\mathbb{E}\{||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}\nabla\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}\},
≈𝔼​{‖ℱk​(𝜽)‖2}+𝔼​{‖Δ​𝜽~k‖2}​𝔼​{‖∇ℱk​(𝜽)‖2},absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscriptℱ𝑘𝜽2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~Δ𝜽𝑘2𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽2\displaystyle\approx\mathbb{E}\{||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}\}+\mathbb{E}\{||\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}||^{2}\}\mathbb{E}\{||\nabla\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}\},
≈𝔼​{‖ℱk​(𝜽)‖2}+(σ~2+σk2)​‖𝐠​(𝜽k)‖2,absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscriptℱ𝑘𝜽2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2superscriptnorm𝐠subscript𝜽𝑘2\displaystyle\approx\mathbb{E}\{||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}\}+(\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2})||\mathbf{g}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})||^{2}, (13)

where the first term in (13) corresponds to the minimization of the loss function with perfect estimation and the second term is the additional cost due to noise. The expectation-based loss in (13) provides a good approximation under the effect of uncertainties due to the noise by adding the regularizer term (σ~2+σk2)​‖𝐠​(𝜽k)‖2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2superscriptnorm𝐠subscript𝜽𝑘2(\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2})||\mathbf{g}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})||^{2} [34, 31]. Similarly, the loss function in (7b) for inactive clients at the PS can be regularized as

ℱ~k​(𝜽)=ℱk​(𝜽)+σ~2​‖𝐠​(𝜽k)‖2.subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽superscript~𝜎2superscriptnorm𝐠subscript𝜽𝑘2\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\tilde{\sigma}^{2}||\mathbf{g}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})||^{2}. (14)

The combination of (8b), (12) and (14) yields the regularized version of the HFCL problem as

Client::Clientabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{Client:}\hskip 7.0pt 𝜽k=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℱ¯k​(𝜽),k∈ℒ¯,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝜽subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽𝑘¯ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\hskip 5.0ptk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, (15a)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 7.0pt 𝜽k=arg⁡min𝜽⁡ℱ~k​(𝜽),k∈ℒ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝜽subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽𝑘ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\mathcal{L}, (15b)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 7.0pt 𝜽~=1D​{∑k∈ℒDk​𝜽k+∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​(𝜽k+Δ​𝜽k)},~𝜽1𝐷subscript𝑘ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝜽𝑘Δsubscript𝜽𝑘\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\frac{1}{D}\bigg{\{}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{L}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})\bigg{\}}, (15c)

where the training on the active and inactive clients are performed in (15a) and (15b), respectively. To effectively solve (15), the GD algorithm is utilized to find an optimal222The optimality of the proposed approach is subject to finding the minimizer of the loss function ℱ¯k​(𝜽)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) at each iteration via the GD method as in the other FL works [17, 33, 35]. While the global optimality of GD can be guaranteed for shallow neural networks, e.g., with a single layer, it usually reaches to a local optimum for wide and deep learning models [2]. model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} for all clients. Then, the model parameter update is performed iteratively as follows

Client::Clientabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{Client:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽k(t+1)=𝜽k(t)−η​𝐠¯k​(𝜽k(t)),k∈ℒ¯,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝜂subscript¯𝐠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝑘¯ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}-\eta\bar{\mathbf{g}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}, (16a)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽k(t+1)=𝜽k(t)−η​𝐠~k​(𝜽k(t)),k∈ℒ,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝜂subscript~𝐠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝑘ℒ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}-\eta\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}),\hskip 10.0ptk\in\mathcal{L}, (16b)
PS::PSabsent\displaystyle\mathrm{PS:}\hskip 10.0pt 𝜽~(t+1)=1D​∑k∈𝒦Dk​𝜽k(t+1),superscript~𝜽𝑡11𝐷subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t+1)}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t+1)}, (16c)

where 𝐠¯k​(𝜽k(t))=∇ℱ¯k​(𝜽k(t))subscript¯𝐠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bar{\mathbf{g}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})=\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}) and 𝐠~k​(𝜽k(t))=∇ℱ~k​(𝜽k(t))subscript~𝐠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡∇subscript~ℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})=\nabla\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}) denote the gradient of the regularized loss function in (12) and (14), respectively. In (16), (16a) and (16b) compute the parameter updates for active and inactive clients, respectively. Afterwards, the model aggregation is performed at the PS as in (16c), and the aggregated model 𝜽~(t+1)superscript~𝜽𝑡1\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t+1)} is broadcast to the active clients.

III-B Communication Delay During Model Training

The bandwidth resources need to be optimized to reduce the latency of the transmission of both 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} (k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}) and 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} (k∈ℒ𝑘ℒk\in\mathcal{L}) to the PS during training. Let τksubscript𝜏𝑘\tau_{k} be the communication time for the k𝑘kth client to transmit its either dataset (𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} for k∈ℒ𝑘ℒk\in\mathcal{L}) or model parameters (𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} for k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}). We define

τk=dkRk,subscript𝜏𝑘subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘\displaystyle\tau_{k}=\frac{d_{k}}{R_{k}}, (17)

where dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} denotes the number of dataset symbols to transmit and Rk=Bk​ln⁡(1+SNRk)subscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘1subscriptSNR𝑘R_{k}=B_{k}\ln(1+\textsf{SNR}_{k}) is the achievable transmission rate. Herein, Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} and SNRksubscriptSNR𝑘\textsf{SNR}_{k} denote the allocated bandwidth and the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for the k𝑘kth client, respectively. The PS solves minBk⁡maxk∈𝒦⁡τksubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝜏𝑘\min_{B_{k}}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\hskip 6.0pt\tau_{k} to optimize the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the maximum communication delay. This is because the model aggregation in the PS can be performed only after the completion of the slowest transmission for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Although Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} can vary for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} differentiates more significantly than Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} between the inactive (i.e., k∈ℒ𝑘ℒk\in\mathcal{L}) and active (i.e., k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}) clients [36, 37]. Especially, depending on the client type, dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} can be given by

dk={P,k∈ℒ¯dk,k∈ℒ,subscript𝑑𝑘cases𝑃𝑘¯ℒsubscriptd𝑘𝑘ℒ\displaystyle d_{k}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}P,&k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}\\ \textsf{d}_{k},&k\in\mathcal{L}\end{array}\right., (20)

which is fixed to the number of model parameters P𝑃P for the active clients, and to dk=Dk​(Ux​Vx+Uy​Vy)subscriptd𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑈𝑥subscript𝑉𝑥subscript𝑈𝑦subscript𝑉𝑦\textsf{d}_{k}=D_{k}(U_{x}V_{x}+U_{y}V_{y}) for Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} input (∈ℝUx×Vxabsentsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑈𝑥subscript𝑉𝑥\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{x}\times V_{x}}) and output (∈ℝUy×Vyabsentsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑈𝑦subscript𝑉𝑦\in\mathbb{R}^{U_{y}\times V_{y}}) dataset samples.

Since the dataset size is usually larger than the number of model parameters in ML applications, i.e., dk∈ℒ>Psubscriptd𝑘ℒ𝑃\textsf{d}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}>P [19, 12, 11], the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is expected to take longer than the model transmission of the active clients, i.e., τk∈ℒ>τk∈ℒ¯subscript𝜏𝑘ℒsubscript𝜏𝑘¯ℒ\tau_{k\in\mathcal{L}}>\tau_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}} [36]. Previous FL-based works reported that τk∈ℒsubscript𝜏𝑘ℒ\tau_{k\in\mathcal{L}} can be approximately 101010 times longer than τk∈ℒ¯subscript𝜏𝑘¯ℒ\tau_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}} [20, 19]. This introduces a significant delay especially at the beginning of the training since the HFCL problem in (15b) or (16b) can be performed only if 𝒟k∈ℒsubscript𝒟𝑘ℒ\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}} is collected at the PS for the first iteration. To tackle this issue and keep the training continuing, in the following, we propose two approaches, namely, ICpC and SDT in Section IV and V, respectively. Both of these techniques are applied only at the beginning of the training to handle effectively the dataset transmission of the inactive clients.

IV HFCL With Increased Computation-per-Client

Prior to the model training, i.e., at t=0𝑡0t=0, the active clients need to wait until the inactive clients complete the dataset transmission, during which the active clients perform only one model computation. In order to keep the active clients continue model computing during the data transmission of inactive clients, we propose the ICpC approach, wherein the active clients move forward computing local model updates, but do not send them to the PS until the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is completed [15]. This approach improves the convergence rate and the learning performance due to the continuation of the model updates at the inactive clients as similar observations are also reported in [15], in which FL-only training is presented.

The algorithmic steps of the HFCL-ICpC approach are presented in Algorithm 1, for which the inputs are the datasets 𝒟k∈𝒦subscript𝒟𝑘𝒦\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{K}} and the learning rate η𝜂\eta. Different from HFCL, HFCL-ICpC involves with the model updates at the active clients during first communication round, i.e., t=0𝑡0t=0, as in the lines 6−9696-9 of Algorithm 1. Using (17) and (20), and defining Q𝑄Q as the block size, the active clients can perform N=maxk∈ℒ⁡dkQ𝑁subscript𝑘ℒsubscriptd𝑘𝑄N=\frac{\max_{k\in\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k}}{Q} iterations when t=0𝑡0t=0 until the dataset transmission of the inactive clients is completed (Line 101010 of Algorithm 1). Although this method keeps the active clients busy with model computation instead of staying idle, it does not reduce the communication latency at the first iteration. As a result, the active clients perform N𝑁N local updates, which improve the convergence rate from O​(1t)𝑂1𝑡O(\frac{1}{t}) to O​(N2t)𝑂superscript𝑁2𝑡O(\frac{N^{2}}{t}) as compared to HFCL [32].

V HFCL With Sequential Data Transmission

Compared to HFCL and HFCL-ICpC, wherein the first communication round awaits for the completion of the transmission of inactive clients’ datasets 𝒟k∈ℒsubscript𝒟𝑘ℒ\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}, HFCL-SDT involves with the transmission of smaller blocks of datasets. Hence, the data transmission time per communication round is smaller while the total amount of time to transmit 𝒟k∈ℒsubscript𝒟𝑘ℒ\mathcal{D}_{k\in\mathcal{L}} to the PS is the same as in HFCL and HFCL-ICpC.

The algorithmic steps of the HFCL-SDT approach are given in Algorithm 1. Let Q𝑄Q be the block size of each portion. The number of blocks can be calculated as N=maxk∈ℒ⁡dkQ𝑁subscript𝑘ℒsubscriptd𝑘𝑄N=\frac{\max_{k\in\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k}}{Q}, which aims at minimizing the latency when t=0𝑡0t=0 by taking into account the largest dataset in terms of maxk∈ℒ⁡dksubscript𝑘ℒsubscriptd𝑘\max_{k\in\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k} since we need to wait until the transmission of the largest dataset. If dk1=dk2subscriptdsubscript𝑘1subscriptdsubscript𝑘2\textsf{d}_{k_{1}}=\textsf{d}_{k_{2}} for k1,k2∈ℒsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2ℒk_{1},k_{2}\in\mathcal{L}, the size of the transmitted data for all clients becomes the same and equals to Q𝑄Q333As a special case, Q=P𝑄𝑃Q=P can be selected to allow the transmitted data from both inactive and active clients is equal. However, this is only possible if N=maxk∈​ℒ⁡dkP<γ​T𝑁subscriptsubscript𝑘ℒsubscriptd𝑘𝑃𝛾𝑇N=\frac{\max_{k_{\in}\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k}}{P}<\gamma T so that dataset transmission is completed before γ​T𝛾𝑇\gamma T iterations. If γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, then both dataset transmission and the training are completed at the same time, which is not efficient. Empirically, γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 is a good choice.. If N𝑁N is not an integer, then N=⌈maxk∈ℒ⁡dkQ⌉𝑁subscript𝑘ℒsubscriptd𝑘𝑄N=\lceil\frac{\max_{k\in\mathcal{L}}\textsf{d}_{k}}{Q}\rceil can be selected. Let us assume that ℱk​(𝜽)subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is the regression loss as in (2)444The same expression can also be written for the loss function in (II-A)., then, the loss function for the inactive clients in the case of the HFCL-SDT algorithm are computed as

ℱk​(𝜽k(t))={∑i=1t​Q∥f(𝒳k(i)|𝜽k(t))−𝒴k(i)∥2t​Q,t≤N∑i=1Dk∥f(𝒳k(i)|𝜽k(t))−𝒴k(i)∥2Dk,t>N,\displaystyle\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{tQ}\|f(\mathcal{X}_{k}^{(i)}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})-\mathcal{Y}_{k}^{(i)}\|^{2}}{tQ}},\hskip 5.0ptt\leq N&\\ {\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{D_{k}}\|f(\mathcal{X}_{k}^{(i)}|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)})-\mathcal{Y}_{k}^{(i)}\|^{2}}{D_{k}}},\hskip 5.0ptt>N&\\ \end{array}\right., (23)

as given in lines 6−146146-14 of Algorithm 1. The size of the training dataset, collected at the PS (i.e., t​Q𝑡𝑄tQ) for ℱk​(𝜽k(t))subscriptℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}), becomes larger as t→N→𝑡𝑁t\rightarrow N, and becomes equal to Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} when t=N𝑡𝑁t=N. When t>N𝑡𝑁t>N, ℱk​(𝜽k(t))subscriptℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}) is computed for the whole dataset of inactive clients for k∈ℒ𝑘ℒk\in\mathcal{L}, as in the 111111th step of Algorithm 1. While the size of the transmitted data from the inactive clients changes, the size of the transmitted information is fixed as P𝑃P for the active clients. This approach not only reduces the latency of the inactive clients, but also improves the learning accuracy as compared to HFCL since the features in the data are quickly learned at the PS due to the use of smaller datasets at the beginning. As a result, the model parameters corresponding to the inactive clients are computed in a mini-batch learning way, in which the dataset is partitioned into mini-batches of size Q𝑄Q. Thus, the convergence rate of the inactive clients in HFCL-SDT is O​(1Q​t+1t)𝑂1𝑄𝑡1𝑡O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{Qt}}+\frac{1}{t}) while the rate of active clients is O​(1t)𝑂1𝑡O(\frac{1}{t}) [38].

VI Complexity Analysis and Communication Overhead

In this section, we investigate the efficiency of the proposed HFCL framework in terms of complexity and communication overhead.

VI-A Complexity Analysis

The complexity of the learning schemes, i.e., CL, FL and HFCL, can be analyzed in terms of convergence speed since the computation of the model parameters is done by solving the optimization problems (II-A), (4) and (16) via GD during training [39, 17, 31]. Specifically, solving the optimization problems (II-A), (4) and (16) for in CL, FL and HFCL, respectively, yields the same convergence rate of O​(1/t)𝑂1𝑡O(1/t) although the accuracy of these algorithms differ depending on the noise corruption (σ~2superscript~𝜎2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} and σk2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\sigma_{k}^{2}) on the model parameters [17]. In particular, CL has higher learning accuracy than FL and HFCL since the model parameters are noise-free in CL while the accuracy of HFCL is between CL and FL since only a part of the model parameters (of inactive clients) are noise-free (see, e.g., Fig. 5). Furthermore, the convergence rates of the proposed HFCL techniques, HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT, are different from those of CL, FL and HFCL since they involve the participation of both active and inactive clients during training. In HFCL-ICpC, the convergence rate of solving the optimization problem for inactive clients is O​(1t)𝑂1𝑡O(\frac{1}{t}) while it is O​(N2t)𝑂superscript𝑁2𝑡O(\frac{N^{2}}{t}) for the active clients due to performing N𝑁N local updates per iteration [15]. As a result, the convergence is faster in active clients as compared to the inactive ones. Also in HFCL-SDT, the convergence rates of the active and inactive clients are O​(1t)𝑂1𝑡O(\frac{1}{t}) and O​(1Q​t+1t)𝑂1𝑄𝑡1𝑡O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{Qt}}+\frac{1}{t}), respectively, due to the dataset is partitioned into Q𝑄Q mini-batches in inactive clients [38]. Hence, one can conclude that the complexity of HFCL-ICpC is less than HFCL-SDT since the former reaches to convergence faster (see, e.g, Fig. 4). We summarize the convergence rates of the HFCL methods for both active and inactive clients in Table III.

Next, we investigate the convergence of the proposed HFCL framework. In the literature, the convergence of the ML models has been studied for centralized [40] and federated [17, 31] schemes separately. In this paper, we analyze the convergence of the hybrid scenario, in which the convergence of the loss functions for active (ℱ¯k​(𝜽))subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽(\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) and inactive (ℱ~k​(𝜽)subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) clients in the presence of corrupted model parameters. First, similar to the previous studies [17, 31, 15], we make the following assumptions needed to ensure the convergence, which are typical for the ł2subscriptitalic-ł2\l_{2}-norm regularized linear regression, logistic regression, and softmax classifiers.

Assumption 1: The loss function ℱk​(𝜽)subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is convex, i.e., ℱk​((1−λ)​𝜽+λ​𝜽′)≤(1−λ)​𝜽​ℱk​(𝜽)+λ​ℱk​(𝜽′)subscriptℱ𝑘1𝜆𝜽𝜆superscript𝜽′1𝜆𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽𝜆subscriptℱ𝑘superscript𝜽′\mathcal{F}_{k}((1-\lambda)\boldsymbol{\theta}+\lambda\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\leq(1-\lambda)\boldsymbol{\theta}\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\lambda\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}) for λ∈[0,1]𝜆01\lambda\in[0,1] and arbitrary 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} and 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}.

Assumption 2: ℱk​(𝜽)subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is L-Lipschitz, i.e., ‖ℱk​(𝜽)−ℱk​(𝜽′)‖≤L​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖normsubscriptℱ𝑘𝜽subscriptℱ𝑘superscript𝜽′𝐿norm𝜽superscript𝜽′||\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})||\leq L||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}|| for arbitrary 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} and 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}.

Assumption 3: ℱk​(𝜽)subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is β𝛽\beta-Smooth, i.e., ‖∇ℱk​(𝜽)−∇ℱk​(𝜽′)‖≤β​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖norm∇subscriptℱ𝑘𝜽∇subscriptℱ𝑘superscript𝜽′𝛽norm𝜽superscript𝜽′||\nabla\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla\mathcal{F}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})||\leq\beta||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}|| for arbitrary 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} and 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}.

In order to prove the convergence of the loss functions for inactive and active clients, i.e., ℱ~k​(𝜽)subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) and ℱ¯k​(𝜽)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), we first investigate the β𝛽\beta-Smoothness of ℱ¯k​(𝜽)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

ℱ¯k​(𝜽)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is a β¯¯𝛽\bar{\beta}-Smooth function with ‖∇ℱ¯k​(𝛉)−∇ℱ¯k​(𝛉′)‖≤β¯​‖𝛉−𝛉′‖norm∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝛉∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝛉′¯𝛽norm𝛉superscript𝛉′||\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})||\leq\bar{\beta}||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}||, where β¯=(1+σ~2+σk2)​β¯𝛽1superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2𝛽\bar{\beta}=(1+\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2})\beta.

Proof:

See Appendix A. ∎

Using Lemma 1 and (14), it is straightforward to show that ℱ~k​(𝜽)subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is a β¯¯𝛽\bar{\beta}-smooth function with β~=σ~2​β~𝛽superscript~𝜎2𝛽\tilde{\beta}=\tilde{\sigma}^{2}\beta.

Theorem 1.

At the k𝑘kth active client (k∈ℒ¯𝑘¯ℒk\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}), the loss function ℱ¯k​(𝛉)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝛉\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) satisfies

ℱ¯k​(𝜽(t))−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)≤‖𝜽(0)−𝜽⋆‖2​12​η​1t,subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽0superscript𝜽⋆212𝜂1𝑡\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}\frac{1}{2\eta}\frac{1}{t}, (24)

where the learning rate is subject to η≤1(1+σ~2+σk2)​β𝜂11superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{(1+\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2})\beta}, and 𝛉⋆superscript𝛉⋆\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star} is the minimizer of ℱ¯k​(𝛉)subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝛉\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}).

See Appendix B. ∎

Based on Theorem 1, the loss function of the inactive clients ℱ~k​(𝜽)subscript~ℱ𝑘𝜽\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is said to be convergent with

ℱ~k​(𝜽(t))−ℱ~k​(𝜽⋆)≤‖𝜽(0)−𝜽⋆‖2​12​η​1t,subscript~ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡subscript~ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽0superscript𝜽⋆212𝜂1𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})-\tilde{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}\frac{1}{2\eta}\frac{1}{t}, (25)

where the learning rate obeys to η≤1(1+σ~2)​β𝜂11superscript~𝜎2𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{(1+\tilde{\sigma}^{2})\beta} since the problem for inactive clients is corrupted by the noise Δ​𝜽~=1D​∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​Δ​𝜽k~Δ𝜽1𝐷subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘Δsubscript𝜽𝑘\widetilde{\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} with variance σ~2superscript~𝜎2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} as in (10).

Consequently, if all clients perform CL, i.e., L=K𝐿𝐾L=K, we have σ~2=σk2=0superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘20\tilde{\sigma}^{2}=\sigma_{k}^{2}=0. Conversely, if all clients perform FL, i.e., L=0𝐿0L=0, the noise-free model parameters in (9) will vanish and the noise variance becomes σ~FL2=1D​∑k∈𝒦Dk​σk2superscriptsubscript~𝜎FL21𝐷subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{FL}}^{2}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}\sigma_{k}^{2}. Thus, FL converges with lower learning performance than that of CL [15]. On the other hand, assuming D1=⋯=DKsubscript𝐷1⋯subscript𝐷𝐾D_{1}=\cdots=D_{K} and σ12=⋯=σK2superscriptsubscript𝜎12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐾2\sigma_{1}^{2}=\cdots=\sigma_{K}^{2}, the noise variance in HFCL σ~HFCL2=1D​∑k∈ℒ¯Dk​σk2superscriptsubscript~𝜎HFCL21𝐷subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{HFCL}}^{2}=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}\sigma_{k}^{2} becomes less than σ~FL2superscriptsubscript~𝜎FL2\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{FL}}^{2} since ∑k∈ℒ¯σk2<∑k∈𝒦σk2subscript𝑘¯ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}\sigma_{k}^{2}<\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\sigma_{k}^{2}, where K−L<K𝐾𝐿𝐾K-L<K for L≥1𝐿1L\geq 1. Therefore, the performance of HFCL is upper (lower) bounded by CL (FL) as 0≤σ~HFCL2≤σ~FL20superscriptsubscript~𝜎HFCL2superscriptsubscript~𝜎FL20\leq\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{HFCL}}^{2}\leq\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{FL}}^{2}.

Remark 1: If Dk1≠Dk2subscript𝐷subscript𝑘1subscript𝐷subscript𝑘2D_{k_{1}}\neq D_{k_{2}}, where k1,k2∈𝒦subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2𝒦k_{1},k_{2}\in\mathcal{K} and k1≠k2subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2k_{1}\neq k_{2}, the performance of HFCL may be lower than FL. For instance, assuming that σ12=⋯=σK2superscriptsubscript𝜎12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐾2\sigma_{1}^{2}=\cdots=\sigma_{K}^{2}, if 1D​∑k∈ℒ¯Dk>1D​∑k∈𝒦Dk1𝐷subscript𝑘¯ℒsubscript𝐷𝑘1𝐷subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\bar{\mathcal{L}}}D_{k}>\frac{1}{D}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}, HFCL converges with higher noise than that of FL since σ~HFCL2>σ~FL2superscriptsubscript~𝜎HFCL2superscriptsubscript~𝜎FL2\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{HFCL}}^{2}>\tilde{\sigma}_{\mathrm{FL}}^{2}. While the equality of σk∈𝒦2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝒦2\sigma_{k\in\mathcal{K}}^{2} may be practical, the performance of HFCL and FL is subject to the size of the datasets [15, 17].

VI-B Communication Overhead

The communication overhead is due to the transmission of the dataset or the model parameters that are exchanged between the clients and the PS, wherein several signal processing techniques, such as channel acquisition, quantization, and resource allocation, are employed. Hence, the communication overhead can be measured by the number of transmitted symbols during model training [19, 12, 7, 20]. Regarding the communication overhead of CL (𝒯CLsubscript𝒯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}}), it can be given by the number of symbols used to transmit datasets while the overhead during FL (𝒯FLsubscript𝒯FL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}) is proportional to the number of communication rounds T𝑇T and model parameters P𝑃P. Let D=∑k∈𝒦dkDsubscript𝑘𝒦subscriptd𝑘{\textsf{D}}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\textsf{d}}_{k} be the number of symbols of the whole dataset, then the communication overhead of CL, FL and HFCL are given respectively as

𝒯CLsubscript𝒯CL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}} =D,absentD\displaystyle={\textsf{D}}, (26)
𝒯FLsubscript𝒯FL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}} =2​T​P​K,absent2𝑇𝑃𝐾\displaystyle=2TPK, (27)
𝒯HFCLsubscript𝒯HFCL\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}} =L​dk∈ℒ+2​T​P​(K−L),absent𝐿subscriptd𝑘ℒ2𝑇𝑃𝐾𝐿\displaystyle=L{\textsf{d}}_{k\in\mathcal{L}}+2TP(K-L), (28)

where 𝒯HFCLsubscript𝒯HFCL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}} includes the transmission of the dataset from L𝐿L inactive clients and the model parameters from K−L𝐾𝐿K-L active clients. It is reasonable to assume that the size of the datasets is larger than the size of the model parameters, i.e., 𝒯FL≤𝒯CLsubscript𝒯FLsubscript𝒯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}} [19, 12, 7, 20, 11], which gives 𝒯FL≤𝒯HFCL≤𝒯CLsubscript𝒯FLsubscript𝒯HFCLsubscript𝒯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{FL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{HFCL}}\leq\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}}. Notice that the communication overhead is equal for all HFCL techniques proposed in this work, since they all involve the same amount of dataset and model transmission.

VII Numerical Simulations

In this section, we present the performance of the proposed HFCL frameworks in comparison to traditional CL- and FL-based training. We evaluate the performance on two datasets: i) image classification on the MNIST dataset [41] and ii) 3D object detection on the Lyft Level 5 AV dataset [42].

VII-A Image Classification

We evaluate the performance on the MNIST dataset [41] including 28×28282828\times 28 gray-scale images of handwritten digits with 101010 classes. The number of symbols on the whole dataset is D=282⋅60,000≈47×106formulae-sequenceD⋅superscript2826000047superscript106{\textsf{D}}=28^{2}\cdot 60,000\approx 47\times 10^{6}. During model training, the dataset is partitioned into K=10𝐾10K=10 blocks, each of which is available at the clients with identically independent distribution. Further, we train a CNN with 666 layers. The first layer is 28×28282828\times 28 input layer. The second and the fourth layers are convolutional layers with 5×5555\times 5@128128128 and 3×3333\times 3@128128128 spatial filters, respectively. After each convolutional layer, there is a ReLUReLU\mathrm{ReLU} layer, which operates max​(0,x)max0𝑥\mathrm{max}(0,x) for its input x𝑥x. The output layer is a classification layer, which computes the probability distribution of the input data for 101010 classes. Thus, we have P=128⋅(52+32)=4,352formulae-sequence𝑃⋅128superscript52superscript324352P=128\cdot(5^{2}+3^{2})=4,352 learnable parameters. The validation data of the MNIST dataset include 10,0001000010,000 images. The learning rate is selected as 0.0010.0010.001, which is reduced by half after each 303030 iterations, and the mini-batch size is selected as 128128128 for CL. The loss function was the cross-entropy cost as −1D​∑i=1D∑c=1C¯[𝒴i(c)​ln⁡𝒴^i(c)+(1−𝒴i(c))​ln⁡(1−𝒴^i(c))],1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑐1¯𝐶delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒴𝑖𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝒴𝑖𝑐1superscriptsubscript^𝒴𝑖𝑐-\frac{1}{{{D}}}\sum_{i=1}^{{{D}}}\sum_{c=1}^{\bar{C}}\bigg{[}\mathcal{Y}_{i}^{(c)}\ln\hat{\mathcal{Y}}_{i}^{(c)}+(1-\mathcal{Y}_{i}^{(c)})\ln(1-\hat{\mathcal{Y}}_{i}^{(c)})\bigg{]}, where {𝒴i(c),𝒴^i(c)}i=1,c=1D,C¯superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒴𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒴𝑖𝑐formulae-sequence𝑖1𝑐1𝐷¯𝐶\{\mathcal{Y}_{i}^{(c)},\hat{\mathcal{Y}}_{i}^{(c)}\}_{i=1,c=1}^{{{D}},\bar{C}} are the true and predicted response for the classification layer with C¯=10¯𝐶10\bar{C}=10. The classification accuracy is Accuracy(%)=UD×100,\mathrm{Accuracy}(\%)=\frac{\textsf{U}}{{D}}\times 100, in which the model identified the image class correctly U times. Further, we define the SNR during model transmission as SNR𝜽=20​log10⁡‖𝜽‖22σ𝜽2subscriptSNR𝜽20subscript10superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜽22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜽2\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20\log_{10}\frac{||\boldsymbol{\theta}||_{2}^{2}}{{\sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2}}, where σ𝜽2=σ~2+σk2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜽2superscript~𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2{\sigma}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2}=\tilde{\sigma}^{2}+\sigma_{k}^{2} denotes the total amount of noise variance during model transmission, for which we assume σL+12=⋯=σK2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐿12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐾2\sigma_{L+1}^{2}=\dots=\sigma_{K}^{2} for simplicity.

Fig. 2 shows the communication overhead of CL, FL, and HFCL for L={0,1,3,5,7,10}𝐿0135710L=\{0,1,3,5,7,10\}. During model training, we assume that 100010001000 data symbols are transmitted at each transmission block. Thus, it takes approximately 47×10347superscript10347\times 10^{3} transmission blocks to complete CL-based training, while FL demands approximately 8,5×10385superscript1038,5\times 10^{3} data blocks, which are approximately 666 times lower than that of CL. The communication overhead of HFCL (as well as HFCL-SDT and HFCL-ICpC) is between CL and FL since it depends on the number of inactive clients L𝐿L and approaches to 𝒯CLsubscript𝒯CL\mathcal{T}_{\mathrm{CL}} as L→K→𝐿𝐾L\rightarrow K.

To explicitly present the overhead for the hybrid frameworks, the number of transmitted symbols before (t=0𝑡0t=0) and during (t>0𝑡0t>0) training is presented in Fig. 3. Specifically, the whole communication overhead of CL is at t=0𝑡0t=0 before training due the dataset transmission. In contrast, the overhead of FL is observed during training since no dataset transmission is involved, yet model transmission is taken place when t>0𝑡0t>0. For the HFCL algorithms, they involve communication overheads before and during training since they involve both dataset and model transmission. Also, it is clear that the overhead of all hybrid frameworks are the same because they all involve the same amount of dataset and model transmission. However, they are distinguished in terms of the number of symbols transmitted before and during training. While HFCL and HFCL-ICpC have the same amount of overhead during training, HFCL-SDT has a lower overhead before training due to transmitting the datasets sequentially. Furthermore, we see that the overhead of FL is twice the amount during training for HFCL and HFCL-ICpC. This is because L=5𝐿5L=5 for HFCL and HFCL-ICpC, and L=K=10𝐿𝐾10L=K=10 for FL. While the overhead of FL may seem lower compared to our HFCL frameworks, the former does not work if the clients have no capability for model computation, which is taken into account in the latter frameworks at the cost of a moderate increase in the overhead.

In Fig. 4, we present the training performance of the competing methods for L=5𝐿5L=5, SNR𝜽=20subscriptSNR𝜽20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB, and B=5𝐵5B=5 quantization bits with respect to number of communication rounds. Note that we assume the dataset transmission is completed in CL prior to the training, and the completion of each communication round in FL corresponds to each iteration in CL. HFCL-ICpC has a higher accuracy at the beginning of the training due to multiple updates at the active clients, and it keeps outperforming HFCL and HFCL-SDT for the remaining iterations. Thanks to STD, HFCL-SDT also has higher performance than HFCL, which performs better than conventional FL. Notice that all the proposed HFCL approaches have moderate performance between FL and CL, as theoretically proved in Section VI. We note that the performance of FL is computed by assuming that all K𝐾K clients participate in training, which is not possible if there exist inactive clients, for which FL is not the applicable training framework.

Fig. 5 shows the classification accuracy with respect to the number of inactive clients L𝐿L when SNR𝜽=20subscriptSNR𝜽20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB. The proposed HFCL approaches perform better than FL for 0<L<K0𝐿𝐾0<L<K since, in FL, the collected models from the active clients are corrupted by the wireless channel whose effects reduce as L→K→𝐿𝐾L\rightarrow K. When L=0𝐿0L=0, HFCL, HFCL-SDT, and HFCL-ICpC are identical to FL since all the clients are active whereas they perform the same as CL if L=K=10𝐿𝐾10L=K=10 since all the clients are inactive, i.e., they transmit their datasets to the PS, and the noise-free model parameters can be used for model training. Comparing the HFCL algorithms, it yields that both HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT provide higher accuracy than HFCL for 0<L<K0𝐿𝐾0<L<K. HFCL-ICpC starts the training process when t=0𝑡0t=0 with locally-updated models at the active clients, thus, it provides a higher accuracy than both HFCL and HFCL-SDT. Also, HFCL-SDT starts the training with the same conditions as in HFCL while HFCL-SDT incorporates smaller datasets at the beginning for t<N𝑡𝑁t<N. Thus, higher accuracy levels are reached quicker than HFCL, which computes the model parameters on the whole local dataset of the inactive clients for t<N𝑡𝑁t<N, leading to a slower convergence rate.

In Fig. 5, we also present the performance of FL with only L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} active clients where L¯=K−L¯𝐿𝐾𝐿\bar{L}=K-L is the number of active clients. That is to say, the learning model is trained on only the dataset of active clients, whereas it is tested on the whole dataset. We also consider the scenario that the training is conducted by only L¯−2¯𝐿2\bar{L}-2 active clients, two of which do not participate into the training due to the privacy concerns or limited conditions, such as having very low channel gain [33, 43]. We observe that FL becomes unable to learn the data as L𝐿L increases since the training is conducted only on the datasets of active clients. This shows the effectiveness of the proposed HFCL approach, in which all of the clients participate in the learning stage. It is worthwhile to note that when L=K=10𝐿𝐾10L=K=10, there will be no active clients, hence FL will not be performed. The performance loss can be severe as L→K→𝐿𝐾L\rightarrow K due to the absence of inactive clients’ datasets if the dataset is non-identically distributed because the active clients cannot learn the whole features in the dataset of other devices.

We further present the classification performance with respect to the noise corruption on the model parameters for both identically independent distribution (IID) and non-IID cases in Fig. 6a and Fig. 6b, respectively. In IID scenario, the dataset is uniform randomly shuffled over the clients while for non-IID case, the dataset is sorted by labels and each client is then randomly assigned with 1 or 2 labels [15, 35]. We compare the classification accuracy of the proposed HFCL methods with existing advanced FL techniques, i.e., FedAvg [15] and FedProx [44]. Specifically, in FedAvg, all the clients apply N𝑁N local model updates in each communication round whereas N=1𝑁1N=1 in conventional FL. Also, the clients employ different number of local model updates in FedProx (i.e., variable N𝑁N) [44]. We set SNR𝜽subscriptSNR𝜽\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} as SNR𝜽=[0,20]subscriptSNR𝜽020\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=[0,20] dB and SNR𝜽=SNR𝒟subscriptSNR𝜽subscriptSNR𝒟\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\mathrm{SNR}_{\mathcal{D}}, which is defined as the SNR of the noise added onto the transmitted datasets. We can see from Fig. 6 that the FL-based methods (e.g., FedAvg, FedProx and FL) are exposed to approximately 4.5%percent4.54.5\% loss in the learning accuracy while the HFCL methods perform 3.5%percent3.53.5\% poorer due to non-IID datasets. The slight performance improvement of HFCL methods can be attributed to the computation of model parameters at the PS. Furthermore, we observe that FedAvg has superior performance than FL due to multiple local model updates while FedProx performs better due to performing different number of local updates. Nevertheless, the proposed HFCL techniques have higher accuracy due to the computation of the model updates (of inactive clients) in the PS. As expected, compared to the FL-based methods and the proposed hybrid algorithms, CL is more robust against noise because its model parameters are not corrupted by wireless transmission since they are computed at the PS. Comparing the effect of noise in datasets and model parameters, it can be concluded that the learning accuracy depends more on the corruptions in the model than the datasets. This is because the noise in the model makes it unable to learn the data while the noise in the dataset is, to some extend, helpful to make the model robust against the imperfections in the data. Therefore, artificial noise is usually added onto the dataset in many applications, such as image classification [2, 3], and physical layer design in wireless communications [20, 25].

In Fig. 7, we present the classification accuracy with respect to the quantization level of the model parameters for B∈[1,8]𝐵18B\in[1,8] when SNR𝜽=20subscriptSNR𝜽20\mathrm{SNR}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=20 dB. Note that the quantization is only applied to wireless-transmitted models, i.e., FL, FedAvg, FedProx and HFCL. Hence, the performance of CL does not change. The model parameters are quantized layer by layer between the maximum and minimum weights of each layer [14]. As expected, the classification accuracy improves as B𝐵B increases due to the enhancement of the model precision. We can conclude that at least a 555-bit quantization is required for a reliable classification accuracy.

VII-B 3D Object Detection

We evaluate the performance of the HFCL framework on the 3D object detection problem in vehicular networks, based on the Lyft Level 5 AV dataset [42], collected from lidar and cameras mounted on vehicles [6]. The input data are selected as a top view image of the ego vehicle, which includes the received lidar signal strengths for different elevations, as shown in Fig. 8a. The output data are the classified representation of the vehicles/objects as boxes, which are obtained by the preprocessing of the images from the cameras, as illustrated in Fig. 8a 555While we assumed that the dataset is labeled, the annotation of the objects in the data samples is an important task, for which the reader can refer to [6, 7].. The training dataset is collected from 101010 vehicles in different areas after preprocessing of the camera and lidar data. We assume that L=3𝐿3L=3 of the vehicles are inactive while the remaining ones are active clients. Each dataset includes 103superscript10310^{3} input-output pairs, whose sizes are 336×336×33363363336\times 336\times 3 and 336×336×13363361336\times 336\times 1, respectively. Hence, the total number of data symbols are (336×336×3+336×336)×104≈4.5×1093363363336336superscript1044.5superscript109(336\times 336\times 3+336\times 336)\times 10^{4}\approx 4.5\times 10^{9}. The dataset has 999 classes, i.e., carcar\mathrm{car}, motorcyclemotorcycle\mathrm{motorcycle}, busbus\mathrm{bus}, bicyclebicycle\mathrm{bicycle}, trucktruck\mathrm{truck}, pedestrianpedestrian\mathrm{pedestrian}, other​vehicleothervehicle\mathrm{other}\hskip 2.0pt\mathrm{vehicle}, animalanimal\mathrm{animal}, and emergency​vehicleemergencyvehicle\mathrm{emergency}\hskip 2.0pt\mathrm{vehicle}, which are represented by the boxes as shown in Fig. 8a. We have used the U-net [45] with 888 convolutional layers to learn the features in the input data and achieve 3D object detection and segmentation. The total number of parameters in U-net is approximately 2×1062superscript1062\times 10^{6}, and the training is conducted for T=40𝑇40T=40 communication rounds.

The training performance of the competing methods is presented in Fig. 8b, from which we obtain similar observations as in the image classification scenario in the previous part. HFCL methods provide a moderate performance between CL and FL. Nevertheless, all of the vehicles can participate in training while the conventional FL methods cannot support it and the communication overhead of CL is prohibitive. Thus, HFCL provides a solution for the the trade-off between the computational capabilities of the clients and the communication overhead.

In Fig.8c, the numbers of transmitted data symbols for CL, FL and HFCL are presented. The overhead of CL is due to the transmission of whole data symbols, i.e., approximately 4.5×1094.5superscript1094.5\times 10^{9}. In contrast, the complexity of FL is due to the two way (edge ⇆⇆\leftrightarrows server) transmission of the model updates during training until convergence, i.e., 2×40×(2×106)=160×1062402superscript106160superscript1062\times 40\times(2\times 10^{6})=160\times 10^{6} for 404040 iterations. As a result, FL and HFCL have approximately 282828 and 333 times lower communication overhead compared to CL, respectively. The effectiveness of HFCL in terms of overhead is reduced compared to the image classification application because of the larger input size of the object detection problem (i.e., 336×336×33363363336\times 336\times 3 versus 28×28×12828128\times 28\times 1).

VIII Summary

In this paper, we introduced a hybrid federated and centralized learning (HFCL) approach for distributed ML tasks. The proposed approach is helpful if a portion of the edge devices do not have the computational capability for model computation during training, which is quite common in practice. In order to train the learning model collaboratively, only the active devices, which have sufficient computational capability, perform FL by computing the model updates on their local datasets whereas the remaining inactive devices, which do not have enough computational power, resort to CL and send their local datasets to the PS, which performs the model computation on behalf of them. As a result, HFCL provides a novel solution achieving a trade-off between FL and CL in terms of computation capability of edge devices and communication overhead. Moreover, the transmission of local datasets may generate delays during training if the dataset size of the inactive clients is large. We suggested a mitigation of this problem by proposing HFCL-ICpC and HFCL-SDT frameworks. While the former improves the learning accuracy with a model computation-per-client, the latter reduces the size of the transmitted datasets. Compared to CL, the proposed approach is more advantageous due to the reduction in the communication latency. In the meantime, compared to FL, a drawback of the proposed HFCL approach is that HFCL requires the dataset transmission of the inactive clients, which may raise privacy concerns, however, these are already apparent in CL. Nevertheless, HFCL provides access to the dataset of all devices regardless of their computational capability whereas, in FL, only the dataset of the inactive clients could be used. We showed that our HFCL approach has a significant performance improvement as compared to FL-based training with only active clients since FL cannot access the dataset of all clients. As a future work, we plan to study the application of HFCL to physical layer applications, such as channel estimation, resource allocation, and beamforming. Furthermore, the noisy learning model may not represent the practical case, hence requires further research on realistic modeling.

ℱ¯k​(𝜽′)−limit-fromsubscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})- ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)≤subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆absent\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq
12​η​(‖𝜽−𝜽⋆‖2−‖𝜽−𝜽⋆−η​∇ℱ¯k​(𝜽)‖2),12𝜂superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽⋆2superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽⋆𝜂∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽2\displaystyle\frac{1}{2\eta}\bigg{(}||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}-||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}-\eta\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}\bigg{)}, (37)

which is obtained after incorporating the expansion of ‖𝜽−𝜽⋆−η​∇ℱ¯k​(𝜽)‖2superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽⋆𝜂∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽2||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}-\eta\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta})||^{2}. Substituting the GD update 𝜽′=𝜽−η​∇ℱ¯k​(𝜽)superscript𝜽′𝜽𝜂∇subscript¯ℱ𝑘𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{\theta}-\eta\nabla\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) into (B), we have

ℱ¯k​(𝜽′)−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)≤12​η​(‖𝜽−𝜽⋆‖2−‖𝜽′−𝜽⋆‖2).subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽′subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆12𝜂superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽′superscript𝜽⋆2\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\frac{1}{2\eta}\bigg{(}||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}-||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}\bigg{)}. (38)

Now, let us replace 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime} with 𝜽(i)superscript𝜽𝑖\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(i)}, then summing over i=1,…,t𝑖1…𝑡i=1,\dots,t yields

∑i=1t(ℱ¯k​(𝜽(i))−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆))superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑖subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{t}(\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(i)})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}))
≤∑i=1t12​η​(‖𝜽(i−1)−𝜽⋆‖2−‖𝜽(i)−𝜽⋆‖2)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡12𝜂superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑖1superscript𝜽⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑖superscript𝜽⋆2\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i=1}^{t}\frac{1}{2\eta}\bigg{(}||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(i-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}-||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(i)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}\bigg{)}
=12​η​(‖𝜽(0)−𝜽⋆‖2−‖𝜽(t)−𝜽⋆‖2)absent12𝜂superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽0superscript𝜽⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽⋆2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2\eta}\bigg{(}||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}-||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}\bigg{)}
≤12​η​‖𝜽(0)−𝜽⋆‖2,absent12𝜂superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽0superscript𝜽⋆2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2\eta}||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}, (39)

where the summation on the right hand side disappears since the consecutive terms cancel each other. Since ℱ¯k​(𝜽(t))subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) is a decreasing function, we have

ℱ¯k​(𝜽(t))−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)≤1t​∑i=1t(ℱ¯k​(𝜽(i))−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)).subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑖subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\frac{1}{t}\sum_{i=1}^{t}(\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(i)})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})). (40)

Inserting (39) into (40), we finally have

ℱ¯k​(𝜽(t))−ℱ¯k​(𝜽⋆)≤12​η​t​‖𝜽(0)−𝜽⋆‖2.subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡subscript¯ℱ𝑘superscript𝜽⋆12𝜂𝑡superscriptnormsuperscript𝜽0superscript𝜽⋆2\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})-\bar{\mathcal{F}}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\frac{1}{2\eta t}||\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}||^{2}. (41)
